description: make - GNU make utility to maintain groups of programs

global_flags.description: Unconditionally make all targets.
Use the latest mtime between symlinks and target.

debugging  information  in  addition  to normal processing.  If the FLAGS are omitted, then the behavior is the same as if -d was specified.  FLAGS may be a for all debugging output (same as using -d), b for basic debugging, v for more verbose basic debugging, i for showing implicit rules, j for details on invocation of commands, and m for debugging while remaking makefiles.  Use  n  to  disable  all previous debugging flags.

to directory dir before reading the makefiles or doing anything else.  If multiple -C options are specified, each is interpreted relative to the previous one: -C / -C etc is equivalent to -C /etc.  This is typically used with recursive invocations of make.
Print this message and exit.
Ignore errors from recipes.

If several -I options are used to specify several directories, the directo‐ ries  are  searched  in  the order specified.  Unlike the arguments to other flags of make, directories given with -I flags may come di‐ rectly after the flag: -Idir is allowed, as well as -I dir.  This syntax is allowed for compatibility with the C preprocessor's -I flag.

option is given without an argument, make will not limit the number of jobs that can run simultaneously. When make invokes a sub- make, all instances of make will coordinate to run the specified number of jobs at a time; see the section PARALLEL MAKE AND THE JOB‐ SERVER for details.
option make uses to pass the jobserver pipe read and write file descriptor numbers to sub-makes; see the section PARALLEL MAKE AND THE JOBSERVER for details
While the target that failed, and those that depend on it, cannot be remade, the other de‐ pendencies of these targets can be processed all the same.
With no argument, removes a previous load limit.
Also clear out the default list of suffixes for suffix rules.
Disable the built-in variable settings.
the  effect of the -k option.  This is never necessary except in a recursive make where -k might be inherited from the top-level make via MAKEFLAGS or if you set -k in MAKEFLAGS in your environment.
a message containing the working directory before and after other processing. This may be useful for tracking down errors from complicated nests of recursive make commands.
Echo recipes (disable --silent mode).
Essen‐ tially the file is treated as very old and its rules are ignored.

If type is not specified or is target the output from the entire recipe for each target is grouped together.  If  type is  line the output from each command line within a recipe is grouped together.  If type is recurse output from an entire recursive make is grouped together.  If type is none output synchronization is disabled.
as  otherwise  speci‐ fied.  This also prints the version information given by the -v switch (see below).  To print the data base without trying to remake any files, use make -p -f/dev/null.
Do not run any commands, or print anything; just return an exit status that is zero if the specified targets are al‐ ready up to date, nonzero otherwise.
Don't echo recipes.
This is used  to  pretend  that  the commands were done, in order to fool future invocations of make.
Print tracing information.
Print the version number of make and exit.
Warn when an undefined variable is referenced.

When used with the -n flag, this shows you what would happen if you were to modify that file.  Without -n, it is almost the same as running a touch command on the given file before running make, except that the  modifi‐ cation time is changed only in the imagination of make.
Evaluate STRING as a makefile statement.
Ignored for compatibility.

Print debugging information in addition to normal processing.  The debugging information says which files are being considered  for  re‐ making, which file-times are being compared and with what results, which files actually need to be remade, which implicit rules are con‐ sidered and which are applied---everything interesting about how make decides what to do.
